metadata.titleEn: Dataset of reconstructed terrestrial water storage in Mainland China based on precipitation (2002-2019)
metadata.description: These datasets fill the data gap between GRACE and GRACE-FO, they contain CSR RL06 Mascon and JPL RL06 Mascon. They take China as the study area, and the dataset includes "Decimal_time”, "lat”, "lon”, "time”, "time_bounds”, "TWSA_REC" and "Uncertainty" 7 parameters in total. Among them, "Decimal_time” corresponds to decimal time. There are 191 months from April 2002 to December 2019 (163 months for GRACE data, 17 months for GRACE-FO data, and 11 months for the gap between GRACE and GRACE-FO. We have not filled the missing data of individual months between GRACE or GRACE-FO data). "lat" corresponds to the latitude range of the data; "lon" corresponds to the longitude range of the data; "time" corresponds to the cumulative day of the data from January 1, 2002. And "time_bounds" corresponding to the cumulative day at the start date and end date of each month. “TWSA_REC" represents the monthly terrestrial water storage anomalies from April 2002 to December 2019 in China; "Uncertainty" is the uncertainty between the data and CSR RL06 Mascon products. We use GRACE satellite data from CSR GRACE/GRACE-FO RL06 Mascon solutions (version 02), China Gauge-based Daily Precipitation Analysis (CGDPA, version 1.0) data, and CN05.1 temperature dataset. The precipitation reconstruction model was established, and the seasonal and trend terms of CSR RL06 Mascon products were considered to obtain the dataset of terrestrial water storage anomalies in China. The data quality is good as a whole, and the uncertainty of most regions in China is within 5cm. This dataset complements the nearly one-year data gap between GRACE and GRACE-FO satellites, and provides a full time series for long-term land water storage change analysis in China. As the CSR RL06 Mascon product, the average value between 2004.0000 and 2009.999 is deducted from this dataset. Therefore, the 164-174 months (i.e., July 2017 to May 2018) of this dataset can be directly extracted as the estimation of terrestrial water storage anomalies during the gap period. The reconstruction method for the gap of JPL RL06 Mascon is consistent with that of CSR RL06 Mascon.
metadata.instructions:
Datasets are named as "CSRM_TWSA_Rec2002_2019.nc" and "JPLM_TWSA_Rec2002_2019.nc", the data is stored in NetCDF format.
Data reading method: the dataset can be viewed and read by using Matlab/Python/ArcGIS.

background: Terrestrial water storage (TWS) is the sum of all forms of water storage over land surfaces, which plays a key role in the global and regional hydrological cycle. TWS varies on a wide range of temporal and spatial scales, and exerts important effects upon the Earth’s climate system. After the launch of the Gravity Recovery and Climate Experiment (GRACE) satellites in 2002, many studies have quantitatively estimated the TWS or groundwater storage (GWS) changes using GRACE data in global and regional basins. GRACE satellites can derive global monthly temporal gravity fields with a spatial resolution of ~300 km, which can be further used to estimate water storage changes over land when other mass change effects are removed from the gravity fields. However, the lack of in situ observations limits our knowledge of the relationship between natural climate variability, and human activity impacts upon terrestrial water systems. Water resources in basins are mainly influenced by climate changes and anthropogenic activities. Assessing changes in water storage on the global scale under the impact of climate variability and human activity has drawn great attention to the growing water scarcity around the world. On one hand, the climatic fluctuations in ocean and atmosphere, such as El Niño–Southern Oscillation (ENSO), resulting from the large-scale ocean–atmosphere interactions over the equatorial Pacific, can strongly affect global water storage by influencing precipitation patterns. During the warm phase of ENSO (i.e., El Niño), heavy rains generally occur in South America, while droughts occur in Southeast Asia and Australia. On the contrary, during the cold phase of ENSO (i.e., La Niña), heavy rains occur in Southeast Asia and Australia, while droughts occur in Southwestern USA and the West Coast of South America. Other climatic fluctuations, e.g., Pacific Decadal Oscillation (PDO), Indian Ocean Dipole (IOD) and North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO) also impact TWS anomalies (TWSA) at different temporal and spatial scales. On the other hand, due to the increasing water resource management and consumption all around the world, impacts of anthropogenic activities on water storage become more important, and should be taken into account in the hydrologic cycle and modeling. Impacts of direct human activities could be through water withdrawal, the building of reservoirs, or land use and land cover change. Some previous studies have focused on analyzing the relative contribution of TWSA from natural and anthropogenic effects. For instance, Yi et al. estimated an anthropogenic TWS depletion estimate of −187 ± 38 km3/yr in Asia by using a linear relationship between variations in precipitation anomalies and water storage fluxes. Huang et al. isolated the human-induced TWSA by subtracting climate-driven TWSA simulated by models from GRACE-observed TWSA. As GRACE can detect the total TWS changes affected by both climate variability and human activities, whereas land surface model (LSM) simulations generally represent the climate-related TWS changes in most cases. Felfelani et al. quantified the human-induced TWSA by calculating the difference between the two hydrological models, in which human impacts were considered in one model, but not included in the other one. However, there are some limitations and uncertainties in terms of modeling and forcing data. For example, Yi et al. assumed that the anthropogenic component is constant over time, and the climate-driven effect is zero from 1979 to 2015, and they analyzed both impacts on the annual scale. A systematic difference between various precipitation-forcing data was also highlighted. Felfelani et al. also found that the TWSA trend uncertainty caused by the errors in forcing datasets was as high as the TWSA trend differences resulting from different hydrological models. Moreover, global hydrological models and land surface models may exhibit large biases in TWSA amplitude.
research objective: Here we present a quantitative method to isolate these two contributions with reconstructed climate-driven TWS anomalies (TWSA) based on long-term precipitation data. In this study, we aim to isolate climate-driven and human-induced contributions to GRACE-derived TWSA in the HRB on the basis of the statistical reconstruction method.
challenges: However, the lack of in situ observations limits our knowledge of the relationship between natural climate variability, and human activity impacts upon terrestrial water systems. However, there are some limitations and uncertainties in terms of modeling and forcing data. For example, Yi et al. assumed that the anthropogenic component is constant over time, and the climate-driven effect is zero from 1979 to 2015, and they analyzed both impacts on the annual scale. A systematic difference between various precipitation-forcing data was also highlighted. Felfelani et al. also found that the TWSA trend uncertainty caused by the errors in forcing datasets was as high as the TWSA trend differences resulting from different hydrological models. Moreover, global hydrological models and land surface models may exhibit large biases in TWSA amplitude.
methods: We employ the information from the current GRACE record and avoid the difficulties of using hydrological models by using a statistical approach. The upper and lower bounds of the climate-driven TWSA trend (Trend CD) and human-induced TWSA trend (TrendHI) are estimated based on a relatively long time period of reconstructed, climate-driven TWSA time series.
dataset: The GRACE gridded data used in this study covered a total period of 124 months (January 2003 to December 2013). Gridded daily precipitation data over the study region are obtained from the China Meteorological Administration (CMA) for the period of 1961–2013. The reconstruction period is from 1967 for discarding six spin-up years as suggested by Humphrey et al. The gridded data were obtained by partial thin plate smoothing splines interpolation of precipitation observations from 2472 weather stations with daily temporal resolution and 0.5 ◦ × 0.5◦ spatial resolution over the whole of China, and 258 weather stations were used in the HRB.
findings: Using the Haihe River Basin (HRB) as a case study, we find a higher human-induced water depletion rate (−12.87 ± 1.07 mm/yr) compared to the original negative trend observed by GRACE alone for the period of 2003–2013, accounting for a positive climate-driven TWSA trend (+4.31 ± 0.72 mm/yr). We show that previous approaches (e.g., relying on land surface models) provide lower estimates of the climate-driven trend, and thus likely underestimated the human-induced trend. The isolation method presented in this study will help to interpret observed long-term TWS changes and assess regional anthropogenic impacts on water resources.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how researchers might use precipitation data to reconstruct terrestrial water storage anomalies (TWSA)?
Example.Answer: Researchers use precipitation data from sources like the China Meteorological Administration, which provides gridded daily precipitation data, to statistically reconstruct climate-driven TWS anomalies. This involves using precipitation observations interpolated by methods such as partial thin plate smoothing splines, covering extensive temporal and spatial scales, to estimate climate-driven components of TWSA.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when isolating human-induced impacts on water storage changes using GRACE data?
Example.Answer: A significant challenge is the lack of in situ observations to fully understand the relationship between natural climate variability and human activities. Additionally, there are limitations and uncertainties in modeling and forcing data, such as systematic differences in precipitation-forcing data and the uncertainties in TWSA trends due to errors in forcing datasets.

Example.Question: Could you illustrate an example of a methodological approach to estimate contributions to TWS changes from both climate variability and human activities?
Example.Answer: One methodological approach involves using a statistical reconstruction method to estimate the climate-driven TWSA trends and human-induced TWSA trends. This approach uses a long-term reconstructed climate-driven TWSA time series, avoiding the complexities of hydrological models, to determine the upper and lower bounds of these contributions.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'terrestrial water storage (TWS)' in the context of hydrological studies?
Definition.Answer: Terrestrial water storage (TWS) is the sum of all forms of water storage over land surfaces, which plays a key role in the global and regional hydrological cycle. TWS varies on a wide range of temporal and spatial scales and exerts important effects upon the Earth’s climate system. GRACE satellites can derive global monthly temporal gravity fields, which can be used to estimate water storage changes over land when other mass change effects are removed from the gravity fields.

Definition.Question: What does 'climate-driven TWS anomalies (TWSA)' refer to in hydrological research?
Definition.Answer: Climate-driven TWS anomalies (TWSA) refer to variations in terrestrial water storage that are influenced by natural climate variability. These can include fluctuations caused by climatic phenomena such as El Niño–Southern Oscillation (ENSO), Pacific Decadal Oscillation (PDO), Indian Ocean Dipole (IOD), and North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO), which impact TWSA at different temporal and spatial scales.

Definition.Question: What is 'GRACE-derived terrestrial water storage anomalies (TWSA)' in the context of satellite-based hydrological assessments?
Definition.Answer: GRACE-derived terrestrial water storage anomalies (TWSA) are estimates of changes in terrestrial water storage obtained from the Gravity Recovery and Climate Experiment (GRACE) satellites. GRACE can detect total TWS changes affected by both climate variability and human activities by deriving global monthly temporal gravity fields, which are then used to estimate water storage changes over land.

Comparison.Question: How does the method of using GRACE satellite data to estimate terrestrial water storage changes compare to the use of reconstructed climate-driven TWS anomalies based on long-term precipitation data?
Comparison.Answer: GRACE satellite data provides global monthly temporal gravity fields with spatial resolution, which can be used to estimate water storage changes when other mass change effects are removed. In contrast, the method using reconstructed climate-driven TWS anomalies relies on long-term precipitation data to isolate climate-driven and human-induced contributions, avoiding the complexities of hydrological models.

Comparison.Question: How do the challenges of lacking in situ observations affect the modeling of terrestrial water storage changes using GRACE data compared to using reconstructed climate-driven TWS anomalies?
Comparison.Answer: In situ observation limitations affect both GRACE data and reconstructed climate-driven TWS anomalies by introducing uncertainties in the relationship between natural variability and human impacts. However, GRACE-based approaches may face additional challenges due to the dependency on removing other mass change effects, while the reconstruction approach aims to statistically isolate climate-driven TWS anomalies, potentially reducing reliance on imperfect model simulations.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of GRACE satellite data with other environmental datasets reveal insights into the temporal and spatial variations of terrestrial water storage?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of GRACE satellite data with other datasets, such as precipitation and temperature data, allows for a comprehensive analysis of terrestrial water storage (TWS) variations. This approach helps to quantify the contributions of climate-driven and human-induced changes to TWS anomalies, providing a clearer understanding of the hydrological cycle and the impacts of natural and anthropogenic influences on water storage.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways might reconstructed datasets fill the gaps during satellite observation discontinuities, and what potential uncertainties could affect their accuracy?
Interpretation.Answer: Reconstructed datasets can fill observation gaps by using models that account for seasonal and trend components, bridging discontinuities between satellite missions like GRACE and GRACE-FO. However, uncertainties may arise from modeling assumptions and the quality of input datasets, such as precipitation and temperature, which can affect the accuracy of the reconstructed terrestrial water storage changes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the uncertainties and limitations in modeling terrestrial water storage anomalies (TWSA) when using GRACE data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Uncertainties in modeling TWSA when using GRACE data arise from the lack of in situ observations, errors in forcing datasets, and biases in global hydrological models and land surface models. Additionally, assumptions made in previous studies, such as constant anthropogenic components over time or zero climate-driven effects, contribute to these uncertainties.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the errors in estimating human-induced water storage changes using hydrological models?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Errors in estimating human-induced water storage changes using hydrological models are often due to limitations in modeling and forcing data, such as systematic differences between precipitation-forcing datasets and uncertainties in TWSA trend caused by errors in these datasets. Furthermore, previous approaches might underestimate human impacts due to reliance on models that inadequately capture anthropogenic effects.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of utilizing reconstructed climate-driven terrestrial water storage anomalies for understanding anthropogenic impacts on regional water resources?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using reconstructed climate-driven terrestrial water storage anomalies can help isolate human-induced changes from natural climate variability. This approach provides a clearer understanding of anthropogenic impacts on water resources by quantifying human-induced water depletion rates, which may otherwise be underestimated if relying solely on land surface models.

Causal Consequence.Question: What outcomes might arise from addressing the uncertainties in precipitation-forcing data when reconstructing terrestrial water storage anomalies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Addressing uncertainties in precipitation-forcing data when reconstructing terrestrial water storage anomalies can lead to more reliable estimations of both climate-driven and human-induced trends. By refining the accuracy of input data, researchers can reduce biases and trend uncertainties, thereby enhancing the interpretation of long-term water storage changes and assessing regional impacts more effectively.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to develop a dataset that bridges the gap between GRACE and GRACE-FO satellite data in the context of terrestrial water storage analysis?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Developing a dataset that bridges the gap between GRACE and GRACE-FO satellite data is important because it provides a complete time series for analyzing long-term terrestrial water storage changes. This is crucial for understanding the impacts of climate variability and human activities on water resources, especially in regions like China where water scarcity is a growing concern.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind using reconstructed climate-driven TWS anomalies based on long-term precipitation data in water storage studies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective behind using reconstructed climate-driven TWS anomalies based on long-term precipitation data is to isolate the contributions of climate-driven and human-induced changes to terrestrial water storage anomalies. This helps in better understanding the role of natural climate variability and anthropogenic activities in altering water storage, which is vital for effective water resource management.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it necessary to employ a statistical approach rather than hydrological models in estimating climate-driven and human-induced TWSA trends?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Employing a statistical approach rather than hydrological models is necessary to avoid the limitations and uncertainties associated with modeling and forcing data. The statistical method allows for the estimation of upper and lower bounds of climate-driven and human-induced TWSA trends based on a reconstructed time series, providing a more reliable interpretation of long-term TWS changes and regional anthropogenic impacts.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can a dataset be constructed to fill gaps between satellite data periods using precipitation and temperature data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The dataset can be constructed by using a precipitation reconstruction model, which includes data from GRACE and GRACE-FO satellite records, along with CSR GRACE/GRACE-FO RL06 Mascon Solutions and other datasets such as China's daily grid rainfall real-time analysis system and CN05.1 temperature data. This method incorporates seasonal and trend components of Mascon products to fill gaps between satellite data periods.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in isolating climate-driven and human-induced contributions to terrestrial water storage anomalies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedural steps involve using a statistical reconstruction method based on long-term precipitation data. The method uses information from the GRACE record to estimate the upper and lower bounds of climate-driven and human-induced TWSA trends, avoiding the use of hydrological models. This approach helps separate the contributions by utilizing reconstructed climate-driven TWS anomalies over a long period.

Enablement.Question: What data interpolation techniques enable the creation of gridded precipitation datasets from weather station observations?
Enablement.Answer: The gridded data were obtained by partial thin plate smoothing splines interpolation of precipitation observations from 2472 weather stations with daily temporal resolution and 0.5° × 0.5° spatial resolution over the whole of China.

Enablement.Question: How do satellite missions like GRACE and GRACE-FO enable the estimation of terrestrial water storage changes despite data discontinuities?
Enablement.Answer: Satellite missions like GRACE and GRACE-FO enable the estimation of terrestrial water storage changes by deriving global monthly temporal gravity fields with a spatial resolution of ~300 km, which, when combined with other datasets, help bridge data discontinuities during satellite mission gaps.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or datasets enable the isolation of climate-driven and human-induced contributions to terrestrial water storage anomalies?
Enablement.Answer: The isolation of climate-driven and human-induced contributions to terrestrial water storage anomalies is enabled by using reconstructed climate-driven TWS anomalies based on long-term precipitation data and avoiding the difficulties of using hydrological models.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be limitations and uncertainties in modeling and forcing data when estimating terrestrial water storage anomalies?
Expectation.Answer: There are limitations and uncertainties in modeling and forcing data because previous studies have highlighted systematic differences between various precipitation-forcing datasets and errors in forcing datasets that can cause significant uncertainties in terrestrial water storage anomaly trends. Additionally, global hydrological models and land surface models may exhibit large biases in the amplitude of terrestrial water storage anomalies.

Expectation.Question: Why is the lack of in situ observations a challenge for understanding the relationship between natural climate variability and human activity impacts on terrestrial water systems?
Expectation.Answer: The lack of in situ observations is a challenge because it limits our knowledge of how natural climate variability and human activity impact terrestrial water systems, making it difficult to accurately quantify and differentiate the contributions of these factors to terrestrial water storage changes.

Expectation.Question: Why might a statistical reconstruction method be chosen over hydrological models to isolate climate-driven and human-induced contributions to terrestrial water storage anomalies?
Expectation.Answer: A statistical reconstruction method might be chosen over hydrological models to avoid the difficulties associated with using hydrological models, such as their biases and the uncertainties in forcing data. By employing statistical approaches, researchers can estimate the upper and lower bounds of climate-driven and human-induced terrestrial water storage anomaly trends more accurately.

Judgmental.Question: How do researchers evaluate the effectiveness of using reconstructed climate-driven terrestrial water storage anomalies in isolating the impacts of climate variability and human activities?
Judgmental.Answer: Researchers employ a statistical approach using long-term precipitation data to reconstruct climate-driven terrestrial water storage anomalies. By avoiding the complexities of hydrological models, they estimate the upper and lower bounds of climate-driven and human-induced trends. This method helps in isolating the contributions of climate variability and human activities on terrestrial water storage anomalies more effectively.

Judgmental.Question: What challenges might arise from the lack of in situ observations when assessing terrestrial water storage changes, and how can these be mitigated?
Judgmental.Answer: The lack of in situ observations limits understanding of the relationship between natural climate variability and human activity impacts on terrestrial water systems. Challenges include uncertainties in modeling and forcing data. Mitigation can involve using reconstruction methods based on long-term precipitation data, which can provide more accurate estimates of climate-driven contributions to terrestrial water storage anomalies.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could the integration of GRACE satellite data and regional precipitation datasets improve the understanding of terrestrial water storage changes?
Judgmental.Answer: Integration of GRACE satellite data with regional precipitation datasets allows for a comprehensive analysis of terrestrial water storage changes. By reconstructing terrestrial water storage anomalies using precipitation data, researchers can better isolate the effects of climate variability and human activities. This approach can improve the accuracy of water storage change assessments and provide a more complete understanding of hydrological cycles.

Assertion.Answer: The integration involves connecting CSR RL06 Mascon and JPL RL06 Mascon data to bridge the gap between GRACE and GRACE-FO data, using a precipitation reconstruction model and considering seasonal and trend components of Mascon products.

Assertion.Answer: A quantitative method is used to isolate these contributions by reconstructing climate-driven TWS anomalies based on long-term precipitation data, avoiding the complexities of hydrological models.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential methods for overcoming the limitations and uncertainties in modeling and forcing data when estimating terrestrial water storage anomalies.
Request/Directive.Answer: To address the limitations and uncertainties in modeling and forcing data, one method is to use statistical approaches that leverage existing satellite records, such as GRACE, to isolate climate-driven and human-induced contributions. This avoids the difficulties associated with hydrological models. Additionally, employing long-term reconstructed climate-driven terrestrial water storage anomalies based on precipitation data can provide upper and lower bounds for trend estimates, helping to refine and validate the results.

Request/Directive.Question: Please evaluate potential data sources or methodologies that could be used to reconstruct terrestrial water storage changes during satellite data gaps.
Request/Directive.Answer: During satellite data gaps, the reconstruction of terrestrial water storage changes can be achieved by using a combination of datasets, such as GRACE and GRACE-FO Mascon Solutions and daily grid precipitation data. Establishing precipitation reconstruction models and considering seasonal and trend components of Mascon products can help fill these gaps. Utilizing the long-term precipitation data and statistical reconstruction methods can provide a continuous time series for terrestrial water storage changes.
